news_summary: Advancements in science and AI are driving breakthroughs in health, offering hope for paralysis recovery, insights into immune system aging, and a deeper understanding of cellular biology.

articles.title: From science to sport: These are the stories that lifted spirits in 2025
articles.summary: Amid conflicts and crises, 2025 also brought reasons for optimism, medical breakthroughs, encouraging signs for the planet and sporting and cultural surprises. As the world heads into 2026, FRANCE 24 looks back at some of the stories that offered moments of relief.
articles.content:
An Iberian lynx is photographed at the Iberian lynx observatory in Huelva on June 30, 2021.

Welcome to 2026! As the new year begins, FRANCE 24 takes a final look back at the stories that lifted spirits in recent months. From scientific breakthroughs to signs of hope for the planet, there was enough to end 2025 on a high note.

The Sun as never seen before

Scientists had awaited the moment since the 1950s. In July, NASA released the closest images ever taken of the Sun, captured by the Parker Solar Probe.

This image provided by NASA on July 15, 2025 shows solar wind escaping from the surface of the star. ¬© NASA handout, AFP

In the black-and-white images, untrained eyes may see wisps resembling smoke. Experts, however, identify overlapping plasma eruptions and solar wind captured in unprecedented detail, providing valuable data to better understand space weather and the workings of the star.

Read moreüåüThe Bright Side: Solar-skimming probe reveals new insights into space weather threats

Major medical breakthroughs

The generic version of injectable lenacapavir will be available at a price of $40 per year in 120 low and middle-income countries starting in 2027. ¬© AFP

There was also cause for optimism in the medical field. In January, a team of US researchers made a major breakthrough on multiple sclerosis, demonstrating a link between the autoimmune disease ‚Äì which affects more than 2.8 million people worldwide ‚Äì and the Epstein-Barr virus.

The discovery raised hope that vaccination against the virus could one day eliminate one of the disease‚Äôs triggers.

Read moreüåüThe Bright Side: Groundbreaking research on multiple sclerosis wins 'Oscars of science'

Another positive development concerned HIV prevention. Generic versions of injectable lenacapavir, a preventive treatment against the virus that causes AIDS, are expected to become available at a lower cost in around 100 countries from 2027.

The development is expected to greatly expand access to a treatment considered far more practical than a daily pill, particularly in low-income countries.

Fewer smokers in France

This photograph shows a no smoking sign in a shopping mall in Paris on June 3, 2025. ¬© Jo√´l Saget, AFP

"Tobacco is taboo, we‚Äôll beat it", said a French slogan that might just become reality. Last year, the number of smokers in the country declined, especially among young people, according to the French public health agency Sant√© publique France.

Specialists attributed the trend to anti-smoking policies implemented since 2014.

Read moreHow French attitudes to cigarettes are changing

In 2025, the campaign intensified further, with smoking banned on beaches, in parks and in public gardens. The government‚Äôs stated aim is to achieve a tobacco-free generation by 2032.

Countries move to better protect the oceans

This file photo shows a wandering cratena, or nudibranch, in the protected area of France's Porquerolles National Park. ¬© Annika Hammerschlag, AP

It was a strong year for marine life. In June, world leaders met to reinforce the protection of the oceans.

Measures discussed included safeguarding the high seas, strengthening efforts against illegal fishing and expanding marine protected areas.

One commitment has already been fulfilled. After decades of negotiations, states (finally) ratified a treaty on protecting the high seas, providing tools to preserve ocean areas beyond national jurisdiction.

Read moreProtecting the ocean: What is the high seas treaty?

Lynx and turtles rebound

An Iberian lynx is photographed at the Iberian Lynx Observatory of "El Acebuche" at the Donana Natural Park in Huelva, on June 30, 2021. ¬© Cristina Quicler, AFP

The Iberian lynx, recognisable by its pointed ears and spotted coat, recorded a significant recovery. After narrowly avoiding extinction, the species was removed this year from the "endangered" category on the International Union for Conservation of Nature‚Äôs Red List of Threatened Species.

Read moreBouncing back: Spain's Iberian lynx saved from extinction

This year, there were 2,021 Iberian lynxes worldwide, a significant jump from just 94 recorded in 2001.

The green sea turtle also showed signs of recovery. Long hunted for its eggs and shell, it is no longer classified as endangered, highlighting the effectiveness of conservation measures when properly enforced.

European Parliament backs abortion rights

A banner reads "abortion is a human right" ahead of a demonstration marking the International Women's Day in Brussels on March 8, 2025. ¬© Simon Wohlfahrt, AFP

Reproductive rights in Europe also advanced in 2025. On December 17, the European Parliament adopted a resolution urging EU institutions to facilitate access to safe abortions across the bloc.

The move followed a petition signed by more than one million EU citizens. It called for a mechanism enabling people living in countries without access to safe and legal abortion to travel at reduced cost to another EU member state where the procedure is permitted.

The European Commission said it would review the petition before March 2026.

Swimming returns to the Seine

People swim in the River Seine in Paris on July 5 2025, in the first public bathing session in the capital's historic waterway since 1923. ¬© Abdul Saboor, Reuters

After a century and the Paris Olympic Games, a long-held ambition became reality. This summer, thousands of people swam in specially designed areas of the River Seine in the heart of the French capital.

Read moreParisians, tourists take the plunge as Seine reopens amid summer heat

FRANCE 24's journalists also took part in the experience.

To display this content from YouTube, you must enable advertisement tracking and audience measurement. Accept Manage my choices One of your browser extensions seems to be blocking the video player from loading. To watch this content, you may need to disable it on this site. Try again Paris seine ¬© France 24

Haiti and Curacao surprise at the 2026 World Cup

Cura√ßao fans celebrate World Cup 2026 qualification after a 0-0 draw with Jamaica at the National Stadium in Kingston, Jamaica on November 18, 2025. ¬© Ricardo Makyn, AFP

Few observers expected it. Curacao, a Caribbean island with 156,000 inhabitants and an autonomous state within the Kingdom of the Netherlands, qualified for the 2026 Football World Cup.

Read moreCuracao becomes smallest ever country to qualify for football World Cup

Another unexpected qualifier was Haiti. One of the world‚Äôs poorest countries and plagued by gang violence, Haiti also secured a place at the tournament, marking only the second international competition in its history.

Cairo‚Äôs Grand Egyptian Museum opens

Visitors walk through the entrance of the Grand Egyptian Museum (GEM) in Cairo on February 25, 2025, prior to its official opening. ¬© Hasan Mroue, AFP

Egypt inaugurated the Grand Egyptian Museum in November, marking a major moment for history enthusiasts.

The museum, dedicated to the Pharaonic civilisation, houses colossal statues, sarcophagi, tools and jewellery. Nearly 100,000 artefacts are displayed across more than 50,000 square metres of exhibition space.

Read moreFive things to know about the new Grand Egyptian Museum in Cairo

French video game crowned game of the year

Jennifer Svedberg Yen (left) and Guillaume Broche, creators of the video game ‚ÄúClair Obscur: Expedition 33,‚Äù receive the Best Narrative award at The Game Awards at the Peacock Theater in Los Angeles on December 11, 2025. ¬© Michael Tran, AFP

It was the masterpiece no one saw coming. "Clair Obscur: Expedition 33", the debut title from French studio Sandfall Interactive, won multiple awards at the Game Awards ceremony.

Read moreFrench video game 'Clair Obscur' sweeps Game Awards with record nine wins

It marked a first for a French game and a notable achievement for a fantasy universe inspired by Paris in the 1900s, developed by around 30 people on a modest budget.

This article was translated from the original in French by Ana√´lle Jonah.
articles.reasoning: The article highlights multiple significant positive developments in 2025, including major medical breakthroughs such as the link between multiple sclerosis and Epstein-Barr virus, and expanded access to affordable HIV prevention treatment. These breakthroughs have broad, tangible benefits for millions worldwide. Additionally, the article covers other inspiring stories with wide societal and environmental impact, but the strongest and most detailed positive real-world impacts relate to health advancements.
articles.personality_title: 2025's top positive stories: medical breakthroughs, wildlife recoveries, and new cultural milestones
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì 2025 was a year filled with challenges worldwide, but it also brought important moments of hope and progress in science, health, nature, and culture.

**What happened** ‚Äì Scientists captured the closest-ever images of the Sun, helping us understand space weather better. Researchers linked multiple sclerosis, a serious illness affecting millions, to a common virus, opening doors for new vaccines. Affordable HIV prevention treatments will soon be available to many countries. In France, fewer people smoked thanks to strong anti-smoking laws. Ocean protection improved with global agreements to save marine life. The Iberian lynx and green sea turtles showed strong signs of recovery. The European Parliament supported easier access to safe abortions. Paris allowed public swimming again in the Seine River for the first time in 100 years. Unexpectedly, small countries Haiti and Cura√ßao qualified for the 2026 World Cup. Egypt opened a huge new museum about ancient civilization, and a French video game won top international awards.

**Impact** ‚Äì These stories show real progress that affects many people and the planet. The medical discoveries could help millions avoid or manage diseases better. Wildlife recoveries prove that protecting nature works. Better ocean rules help keep ecosystems healthy. Changing laws and public habits improve health and rights. Cultural events like the museum opening and sports surprises bring communities together and inspire pride.

**What's next step** ‚Äì In 2026, the new HIV treatments will start reaching more patients, and the European Commission will review abortion access requests. Scientists will study the Sun‚Äôs data to predict space weather risks. Conservation efforts for animals and oceans will continue to grow. Paris will keep developing safe swimming spots. The World Cup will showcase new teams, and the Grand Egyptian Museum will welcome many visitors. The success of the French video game may encourage more creative projects.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì Despite global challenges, 2025 brought important health advances, environmental wins, and cultural achievements that promise positive changes ahead.

articles.title: A wave paralysed me but AI could help me walk again
articles.summary: Dan Richards, 37, from Swansea was injured in a freak accident on New Year's Eve in 2023.
articles.content:
A wave paralysed me but AI could help me walk again

23 hours ago Share Save Meleri Williams BBC Wales Share Save

After a New Year's Eve swim in 2023, Dan Richards' life changed forever

When Dan Richards went for a New Year's Eve swim in 2023, he never could have imagined how drastically his life would change. In a freak accident, he injured his neck when a wave caused him to flip and hit the sand in Langland Bay, Swansea. "I knew instantly that I was paralysed," the 37-year-old said. "I couldn't move anything." Doctors told him he would be bed-bound but, two years later, he uses a wheelchair and can move his arms and fingers. He has even walked with the help of Artificial Intelligence (AI) technology in Wales and Germany.

Dan and his partner Anna, 40, were celebrating the new year with a cold water dip when the accident happened. "I remember all of it, unfortunately. Being pulled out. And then everything changing," Dan said. "I got hit by a wave, it flipped me over and folded me backwards, and snapped my neck. I knew it was bad."

Anna Thomas Dan is determined to move as much as possible after becoming paralysed

Anna recalled hearing Dan shouting for help as she got ready to get into the water. "I just remember looking over and just seeing Dan's head coming up and then going back under," she said. "We dragged him out. But he was just dead weight and the sea was coming in really fast. "We waited for emergency services, and then [I remember] begging them to let me go in the helicopter. It was horrendous." After being taken to hospital in Bristol, the couple from Swansea were given life-changing news.

Anna Thomas Dan and Anna loved to swim in the sea before the accident

Dan said he was told he was paralysed form the neck down, would not be able to move and it was "highly likely" he would be bed-bound for the rest of his life. Anna - who had only started dating Dan a few months before the accident - had to make dreaded phone calls to family members. "It was New Year's Eve, I was put in a room on my own but you could hear people laughing and joking, and I had to tell Dan's parents. "How do you phone someone's mum and say that their son is paralysed?"

Dan was given life-changing news while in hospital in January 2024

Anna said every day since the accident has brought a new challenge. "It's our reality. Until you're in this situation... you don't realise just how much you have lost." But in the months that followed the accident, when Dan was in hospital, even the slightest movement in his toes gave the couple hope things would change.

Dan and Anna have returned to Wales from Germany to celebrate Christmas

"Luckily I'm quite stubborn," Dan said. "I just wanted to see the physios as soon as possible. I wanted to work. I didn't accept what they were saying. "I'm proud of the progress I've made. It's a long time since laying in bed in Bristol, that's for sure." He continued: "The feeling in my toes then translated into full feeling through my legs and feet, some movement in my right leg [and] core strength - which I was told was gone - started to come back. Movement in my arms, my fingers, being able to hold things. "I'm still hopeful, I'm still positive. With modern technologies, I'm not giving up." Dan had private physiotherapy at a specialist clinic in south Wales which used a world-first combined treatment to help him walk with a machine.

Anna Thomas Family and friends have fundraised for Dan's private physiotherapy treatments

Jakko Brouwers, a neurophysiotherapist from Morello clinic in Newport, said Dan was "an immensely motivated guy" when he visited them after being discharged from hospital. "The technology is two-fold," he explained. "The first part we tried with Dan is a robot. The robot will mimic normal human gait as much as possible. "The other part of the system that we developed is a stimulation suit that has got sensors. The trousers are also fitted with electrodes and we can stimulate muscle activity at the right time. "Through a little bit of algorithm - and dare I say AI - it will start developing a walking pattern. "It's super exciting. It's not often that you see that in Wales."

This robot helped Dan to walk at Morello clinic in Newport shortly after he was discharged from hospital

Dan said the experience was "surreal" but "the best feeling". "It just made me want to push harder. That's on our doorstep here in Wales, so it spurred us on to do some research, and do other things." But private physiotherapy and innovative treatment does not come without cost. From raffles to ultramarathons and charity nights, family and friends have fundraised meaning Dan and Anna could set off for a trial abroad in October.

Anna Thomas Dan and Anna spent two months in Bochum, Germany, for treatment

Dan explained he was trying two different treatments simultaneously in Germany - a stem cell treatment straight into his spinal cord, alongside using a Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) suit, which is a machine that works on brain waves. "It's one of the first times it's ever been done," he said. "Sensors translate signals into movement, which then get my legs working, get me walking. "The more you do it, the stronger the signals get, the faster it gets and eventually you're able to walk without the suit."
articles.reasoning: The article reports on a significant medical and technological breakthrough where AI-assisted rehabilitation and innovative treatments are helping a paralyzed individual regain movement and walk again. This has broad positive implications for spinal injury recovery and showcases hope and progress in health technology with tangible benefits for many people suffering similar conditions.
articles.personality_title: AI and advanced therapy help paralyzed man walk again after accident
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì Dan Richards, 37, from Swansea, was paralyzed after a neck injury caused by a wave accident on New Year's Eve 2023. Initially told he would be bed-bound, Dan has since made remarkable progress using new treatments.

**What happened** ‚Äì After his injury, Dan started physiotherapy that combined a robotic walking machine and a special suit with sensors that stimulate his muscles. This technology uses artificial intelligence (AI) to help create natural walking movements. Dan also traveled to Germany for stem cell treatment and used a machine called the Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL) suit, which helps his brain signals control his legs.

**Impact** ‚Äì Dan‚Äôs recovery is important because it shows how AI and new medical tools can help people with spinal injuries regain movement. This approach is one of the first of its kind in Wales and Germany, offering hope for others facing paralysis. Dan‚Äôs progress from no movement to walking with assistance is a clear example of how technology is changing rehabilitation.

**What's next step** ‚Äì Dan will continue treatments using these AI-based devices and therapies to strengthen his muscles and improve his walking. His experience may lead to wider use of this technology for other patients and inspire further research into combining AI, robotics, and stem cell therapy for spinal injury recovery.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì New AI-powered therapies and robotic devices are helping a man regain movement and walk again after paralysis caused by a neck injury, marking a promising step in spinal injury treatment.
articles.personality_title_fr: L'IA et la th√©rapie avanc√©e aident un homme paralys√© √† marcher √† nouveau apr√®s un accident
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** ‚Äì Dan Richards, 37 ans, de Swansea, a √©t√© paralys√© apr√®s une blessure au cou caus√©e par une vague lors du r√©veillon du Nouvel An 2023. On lui avait d'abord dit qu'il resterait alit√©, mais il a depuis fait des progr√®s remarquables gr√¢ce √† de nouveaux traitements.

**Ce qui s'est pass√©** ‚Äì Apr√®s sa blessure, Dan a commenc√© une physioth√©rapie combinant un robot de marche et un costume sp√©cial avec des capteurs qui stimulent ses muscles. Cette technologie utilise l'intelligence artificielle (IA) pour aider √† cr√©er des mouvements de marche naturels. Dan s'est aussi rendu en Allemagne pour un traitement par cellules souches et a utilis√© un appareil appel√© Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL), qui aide les signaux de son cerveau √† contr√¥ler ses jambes.

**Impact** ‚Äì La r√©cup√©ration de Dan est importante car elle montre comment l'IA et les nouveaux outils m√©dicaux peuvent aider les personnes atteintes de l√©sions de la moelle √©pini√®re √† retrouver des mouvements. Cette approche est l'une des premi√®res de ce genre au Pays de Galles et en Allemagne, offrant de l'espoir √† d'autres personnes paralys√©es. Les progr√®s de Dan, passant de l'absence de mouvement √† la marche assist√©e, illustrent clairement comment la technologie transforme la r√©√©ducation.

**Prochaine √©tape** ‚Äì Dan continuera les traitements avec ces dispositifs et th√©rapies bas√©s sur l'IA pour renforcer ses muscles et am√©liorer sa marche. Son exp√©rience pourrait conduire √† une utilisation plus large de cette technologie pour d'autres patients et inspirer davantage de recherches sur la combinaison de l'IA, de la robotique et de la th√©rapie par cellules souches pour la r√©cup√©ration des l√©sions de la moelle √©pini√®re.

**En une phrase** ‚Äì De nouvelles th√©rapies assist√©es par IA et des appareils robotiques aident un homme √† retrouver le mouvement et √† marcher apr√®s une paralysie caus√©e par une blessure au cou, marquant une avanc√©e prometteuse dans le traitement des l√©sions de la moelle √©pini√®re.
articles.personality_title_es: La IA y la terapia avanzada ayudan a un hombre paralizado a volver a caminar tras un accidente
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** ‚Äì Dan Richards, de 37 a√±os y de Swansea, qued√≥ paralizado tras una lesi√≥n en el cuello causada por una ola en la v√≠spera de A√±o Nuevo de 2023. Al principio le dijeron que estar√≠a postrado en cama, pero desde entonces ha logrado un progreso notable gracias a nuevos tratamientos.

**Qu√© pas√≥** ‚Äì Despu√©s de su lesi√≥n, Dan comenz√≥ una fisioterapia que combina un robot para caminar y un traje especial con sensores que estimulan sus m√∫sculos. Esta tecnolog√≠a usa inteligencia artificial (IA) para ayudar a crear movimientos naturales para caminar. Dan tambi√©n viaj√≥ a Alemania para un tratamiento con c√©lulas madre y us√≥ un aparato llamado Hybrid Assistive Limb (HAL), que ayuda a que las se√±ales de su cerebro controlen sus piernas.

**Impacto** ‚Äì La recuperaci√≥n de Dan es importante porque muestra c√≥mo la IA y las nuevas herramientas m√©dicas pueden ayudar a personas con lesiones de la m√©dula espinal a recuperar el movimiento. Este enfoque es uno de los primeros en Gales y Alemania, ofreciendo esperanza a otros que enfrentan par√°lisis. El progreso de Dan, de no poder moverse a caminar con ayuda, es un claro ejemplo de c√≥mo la tecnolog√≠a est√° cambiando la rehabilitaci√≥n.

**Pr√≥ximo paso** ‚Äì Dan continuar√° los tratamientos con estos dispositivos y terapias basadas en IA para fortalecer sus m√∫sculos y mejorar su caminar. Su experiencia podr√≠a llevar a un uso m√°s amplio de esta tecnolog√≠a para otros pacientes e inspirar m√°s investigaciones en la combinaci√≥n de IA, rob√≥tica y terapia con c√©lulas madre para la recuperaci√≥n de lesiones medulares.

**Resumen en una frase** ‚Äì Nuevas terapias impulsadas por IA y dispositivos rob√≥ticos est√°n ayudando a un hombre a recuperar el movimiento y volver a caminar tras una par√°lisis causada por una lesi√≥n en el cuello, marcando un avance prometedor en el tratamiento de lesiones medulares.
articles.image_prompt: A detailed, warm painting of a serene coastal bay at dawn with gentle waves softly folding over smooth sand, where a symbolic mechanical exoskeleton shaped like a delicate, glowing suit stands upright beside a sturdy wheelchair, both resting near the water‚Äôs edge, bathed in soft natural hues of blue, beige, and muted gold, conveying hope, recovery, and the fusion of human resilience with advanced AI technology.

articles.title: A missing protein may be aging your immune system
articles.summary: As we age, our immune system quietly loses its edge, and scientists have uncovered a surprising reason why. A protein called platelet factor 4 naturally declines over time, allowing blood stem cells to multiply too freely and drift toward unhealthy, mutation-prone behavior linked to cancer, inflammation, and heart disease. Researchers found that restoring this protein in older mice ‚Äî and even in human stem cells in the lab ‚Äî made aging blood and immune cells behave strikingly younger again.
articles.content:
As people grow older, visible changes like gray hair and weaker muscles are only part of the story. Aging also affects the immune system. One major reason is that the stem cells responsible for producing blood and immune cells can accumulate genetic mutations over time, increasing the risk of cancer and other health problems.

Scientists at the University of Illinois Chicago have identified a key biological process behind this shift. Writing in the journal Blood, the researchers report that aging is linked to declining levels of a protein called platelet factor 4. Even more striking, restoring this protein in older blood cells reversed several signs of cellular aging. The findings suggest a potential new target for treating age-related disorders of the blood and immune system.

The Role of Blood Stem Cells in Immune Health

Hematopoietic stem cells, often called blood stem cells, reside in the bone marrow and serve as the foundation of the body's blood and immune systems. These rare cells generate all major types of blood and immune cells needed for oxygen transport and protection against infection.

"Our hematopoietic stem cells are very rare," said UIC's Sandra Pinho, associate professor of pharmacology and regenerative medicine in the College of Medicine. "We call them the Holy Grail of the immune system."

In younger individuals, these stem cells maintain a healthy balance. They produce myeloid cells, which include red blood cells and some immune cells, as well as lymphoid cells, such as T and B cells that play a central role in fighting infections.

Why Aging Stem Cells Lose Balance

As the body ages, blood stem cells begin to favor the production of myeloid cells while generating fewer lymphoid cells. This shift alters immune function and weakens the body's ability to respond to disease.

"That's one of the reasons why, normally, older individuals are not used as donors for bone marrow transplantation, because their stem cells are not as potent," Pinho said.

This imbalance not only affects immunity but also increases vulnerability to age-related diseases.

Platelet Factor 4 and Stem Cell Control

Through studies in mice and human bone marrow samples, the researchers found that platelet factor 4 plays a central role in regulating blood stem cell behavior. In younger people and animals, the protein acts as a signaling molecule that limits how often stem cells divide. This control is especially important for stem cells that produce myeloid cells.

With age, immune cells produce less platelet factor 4. As a result, stem cells divide more frequently and without proper regulation.

"When stem cells start to divide more often than they should, and if their proliferation is not regulated, they can accumulate mutations over time," said Pinho.

In humans, these mutations are linked to chronic inflammation, a higher risk of blood cancers, and even cardiovascular disease.

Reversing Signs of Immune Aging in the Lab

The team discovered that restoring platelet factor 4 could counteract these age-related changes. Older mice received daily blood infusions of the protein for more than a month. After treatment, their blood and immune cells showed behavior and characteristics more typical of much younger animals.

Similar effects were observed in laboratory experiments using human stem cells. When platelet factor 4 was added to aged human cells, the researchers saw a clear improvement in stem cell function.

"It rejuvenated the aging of the blood system," Pinho said.

What This Means for Aging and Disease

While the results are promising, platelet factor 4 alone is not expected to reverse aging throughout the entire body or significantly extend human lifespan.

Though the effect was strong, platelet factor 4 won't be a silver bullet that reverses the aging of all tissues and prolongs the lifespan of elderly human patients alone, Pinho said. However, it could become part of broader strategies aimed at improving age-related conditions.

"It's clear evidence that it's possible to reverse, intrinsically, certain age-associated disorders," Pinho said.

Sen Zhang, a postdoctoral fellow in the Pinho lab, is the study's first author. The research was co-led by Constantinos Chronis from the Department of Biochemistry and Molecular Genetics, who also served as a co-corresponding author. Additional contributors from UIC include Charles Ayemoba, Anna Di Staulo, Kenneth Joves, Chandani Patel, Eva Leung, Maura Bueno, Xiaoping Du and Sang-Ging Ong.
articles.reasoning: The article reports a significant scientific discovery identifying a protein, platelet factor 4, whose restoration can reverse aging signs in blood and immune cells. This breakthrough has broad implications for improving immune health and treating age-related diseases such as cancer and cardiovascular conditions, offering hope for better management of aging-related immune decline.
articles.personality_title: Scientists find protein that can reverse aging in blood and immune cells
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì As people grow older, their immune system becomes weaker partly because the stem cells that create blood and immune cells start to behave abnormally. This can lead to diseases like cancer and heart problems.

**What happened** ‚Äì Researchers at the University of Illinois Chicago discovered that a protein called platelet factor 4 decreases with age, causing blood stem cells to multiply too much and become less healthy. When scientists gave this protein back to older mice and human stem cells in the lab, the cells started acting younger and healthier.

**Impact** ‚Äì This finding is important because it shows a specific reason why the immune system ages and points to a way to fix it. By restoring platelet factor 4, it might be possible to improve the health of blood and immune cells in older people, which could help reduce risks of diseases linked to aging.

**What's next step** ‚Äì Scientists need to study how this protein can be safely used in humans and whether it can help treat age-related diseases. It could become part of new treatments that improve immune health as people get older.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì Restoring the protein platelet factor 4 helps blood stem cells behave younger, offering a new way to improve immune health during aging.

articles.personality_title_es: Cient√≠ficos encuentran prote√≠na que puede revertir el envejecimiento en c√©lulas sangu√≠neas e inmunitarias
articles.personality_presentation_es:

articles.image_prompt: A detailed painting of a glowing, vibrant bone marrow chamber depicted as a warm, nurturing sanctuary where stylized, radiant stem cells gently balance between two flowing streams of blood cells‚Äîone rich with youthful red and white cells symbolizing healthy immunity, the other fading and fragmented‚Äîwhile a soft, golden thread of platelet factor 4 weaves through the scene, restoring harmony and vitality with natural, earthy tones.

articles.title: Some of your cells are not genetically yours ‚Äî what can they tell us about life and death?
articles.summary: Nature, Published online: 31 December 2025; doi:10.1038/d41586-025-04102-4A tiny population of cells that are passed across the placenta between mother and baby challenge basic tenets of human immunology.
articles.content:
Hidden Guests: Migrating Cells and How the New Science of Microchimerism is Redefining Human Identity Lise Barn√©oud, transl. Bronwyn Haslam Greystone Books (2025)

The chimaera of Greek mythology was ‚Äúan evil creature with a lion‚Äôs head, a goat‚Äôs body, and a serpent‚Äôs tail‚Äù, notes journalist Lise Barn√©oud in Hidden Guests. Humans are also chimaeras ‚Äî thanks to the presence of cells that are not our own inside our bodies.

Could baby‚Äôs first bacteria take root before birth?

Mothers carry cells that came from their biological children, passed across the placenta when the baby was in the womb. Likewise, children carry cells that were transferred to them in utero from their mothers ‚Äî some of which might even be from the child‚Äôs maternal grandmothers, older siblings or twin.

These ‚Äòmicrochimeric‚Äô cells have been found in every organ that has been studied so far. But they are also rare ‚Äî much rarer, for example, than the trillions of microorganisms that reside in our guts, on our skin and in many other organs. We carry only one microchimeric cell for every 10,000 to 1 million of our own cells.

In Hidden Guests, the author invites readers to learn about the pioneering ‚Äúmicrochimerists‚Äù ‚Äî scientists who discovered these fascinating shared cells. She also challenges us to consider the broader implications for health and science, and the philosophy of the fact that we are all chimaeras.

Unplanned discovery

Microchimeric cells were, we learn, discovered through a series of accidental observations. In the late 1800s, pathologist Georg Schmorl described ‚Äògiant cells‚Äô in the lungs of people who had died from eclampsia ‚Äî a life-threatening inflammatory condition that can occur during pregnancy. These giant cells resembled the cells of the placenta, leading Schmorl to suggest that fetal cells passing into the bloodstream of mothers was the norm, rather than the exception.

The probiotic home: where microbes are welcome guests

Then, in 1969, a team studying immunity in pregnant people detected white blood cells that contained the Y chromosome in the blood of individuals who would eventually give birth to boys1. For more than two decades, it was presumed that these microchimeric cells were a temporary feature of pregnancy. It wasn‚Äôt until 1993 that geneticist Diana Bianchi found cells with Y chromosomes in women who had given birth to sons between one and 27 years earlier2.

This finding overturned the dogma that children inherit genes from their parents and never the other way around ‚Äî these transferred fetal cells move through the family tree, travelling ‚Äòbackwards in time‚Äô from children to their mothers. Bianchi and others would go on to show that these cells have remarkable regenerative properties ‚Äî promoting wound healing in mothers by transforming into blood vessels or skin cells.

Immunological implications

Microchimerism also calls into question a central tenet of immunology: that the immune system works by classifying cells in a binary fashion, as ‚Äòself‚Äô or ‚Äònon-self‚Äô. Under this simplistic model, microchimeric cells should trigger an immune response and be rejected by the body ‚Äî but they do not. Barn√©oud challenges readers to consider whether forcing microchimerism-related discrepancies to fit into existing immunological rules is appropriate, instead of allowing these cells to influence new immunological rules.

At around the same time that Bianchi was making her groundbreaking discovery, rheumatologist Lee Nelson also found Y-chromosome-containing cells in people who had previously given birth to sons3. Nelson was studying autoimmune diseases, which disproportionately affect middle-aged women, and at the time were thought to be caused by hormone imbalances.
articles.reasoning: The article discusses the discovery and implications of microchimeric cells, which have broad significance for human health and immunology. It highlights a major scientific breakthrough that challenges existing understanding of genetics and immune system function, with potential benefits for regenerative medicine and autoimmune disease research. The story is focused, detailed, and has meaningful impact beyond a niche audience.
articles.personality_title: Scientists uncover cells from mothers and babies living together inside us
articles.personality_presentation:
**Context** ‚Äì Scientists have found that tiny groups of cells can move between a mother and her baby during pregnancy. These cells are called microchimeric cells and are different from the rest of the cells in our bodies.

**What happened** ‚Äì Research over many years showed that mothers carry cells from their children, and children carry cells from their mothers. Some of these cells might even come from the child's grandmother or siblings. These cells were first noticed by accident in the 1800s and confirmed in the 1990s when scientists found cells with Y chromosomes (from boys) in women years after giving birth.

**Impact** ‚Äì This discovery changes what we know about genetics and the immune system. It shows that cells can move 'backwards' from children to parents, which was not thought possible before. These shared cells can help heal wounds and do not cause the immune system to attack them, even though they are not originally part of the person's body. This challenges old ideas about how the immune system works.

**What's next step** ‚Äì Scientists will continue to study these microchimeric cells to understand how they help with healing and how they affect diseases like autoimmune disorders. This research might lead to new treatments that use these cells to repair the body or better understand immune system problems.

**One-sentence takeaway** ‚Äì Tiny cells shared between mothers and babies live inside us and could change how we understand health, healing, and the immune system.
articles.personality_title_fr: Des cellules de m√®re et d‚Äôenfant vivent ensemble √† l‚Äôint√©rieur de nous, selon les scientifiques
articles.personality_presentation_fr:
**Contexte** ‚Äì Les scientifiques ont d√©couvert que de petits groupes de cellules peuvent passer entre une m√®re et son b√©b√© pendant la grossesse. Ces cellules, appel√©es cellules microchim√©riques, sont diff√©rentes des autres cellules de notre corps.

**Ce qui s‚Äôest pass√©** ‚Äì Des recherches sur plusieurs ann√©es ont montr√© que les m√®res portent des cellules de leurs enfants, et les enfants portent des cellules de leurs m√®res. Certaines de ces cellules pourraient m√™me venir de la grand-m√®re ou des fr√®res et s≈ìurs de l‚Äôenfant. Ces cellules ont √©t√© remarqu√©es par accident au 19e si√®cle et confirm√©es dans les ann√©es 1990 lorsque des scientifiques ont trouv√© des cellules avec un chromosome Y (des gar√ßons) chez des femmes des ann√©es apr√®s avoir donn√© naissance.

**Impact** ‚Äì Cette d√©couverte change ce que nous savons sur la g√©n√©tique et le syst√®me immunitaire. Elle montre que les cellules peuvent voyager ¬´ en arri√®re ¬ª des enfants vers les parents, ce qui √©tait auparavant impossible √† imaginer. Ces cellules partag√©es aident √† gu√©rir les blessures et ne sont pas attaqu√©es par le syst√®me immunitaire, m√™me si elles ne font pas partie du corps d‚Äôorigine. Cela remet en question les anciennes id√©es sur le fonctionnement du syst√®me immunitaire.

**Prochaine √©tape** ‚Äì Les scientifiques vont continuer d‚Äô√©tudier ces cellules microchim√©riques pour comprendre comment elles aident √† la gu√©rison et comment elles influencent des maladies comme les troubles auto-immuns. Cette recherche pourrait mener √† de nouveaux traitements utilisant ces cellules pour r√©parer le corps ou mieux comprendre les probl√®mes immunitaires.

**R√©sum√© en une phrase** ‚Äì De minuscules cellules partag√©es entre m√®res et b√©b√©s vivent en nous et pourraient changer notre compr√©hension de la sant√©, de la gu√©rison et du syst√®me immunitaire.
articles.personality_title_es: C√©lulas de madres y beb√©s viven juntas dentro de nosotros, seg√∫n cient√≠ficos
articles.personality_presentation_es:
**Contexto** ‚Äì Los cient√≠ficos han descubierto que peque√±os grupos de c√©lulas pueden pasar entre una madre y su beb√© durante el embarazo. Estas c√©lulas se llaman c√©lulas microquim√©ricas y son diferentes de las dem√°s c√©lulas en nuestro cuerpo.

**Qu√© pas√≥** ‚Äì Investigaciones durante muchos a√±os mostraron que las madres llevan c√©lulas de sus hijos, y los hijos llevan c√©lulas de sus madres. Algunas de estas c√©lulas podr√≠an incluso venir de la abuela o hermanos del ni√±o. Estas c√©lulas fueron notadas por accidente en el siglo XIX y confirmadas en los a√±os 1990 cuando los cient√≠ficos encontraron c√©lulas con el cromosoma Y (de ni√±os) en mujeres a√±os despu√©s de dar a luz.

**Impacto** ‚Äì Este descubrimiento cambia lo que sabemos sobre gen√©tica y el sistema inmunol√≥gico. Muestra que las c√©lulas pueden moverse ‚Äúhacia atr√°s‚Äù de los hijos a los padres, algo que antes no se pensaba posible. Estas c√©lulas compartidas ayudan a sanar heridas y no son atacadas por el sistema inmunol√≥gico, aunque no sean parte original del cuerpo. Esto cuestiona ideas antiguas sobre c√≥mo funciona el sistema inmunol√≥gico.

**Pr√≥ximo paso** ‚Äì Los cient√≠ficos seguir√°n estudiando estas c√©lulas microquim√©ricas para entender c√≥mo ayudan en la curaci√≥n y c√≥mo afectan enfermedades como los trastornos autoinmunes. Esta investigaci√≥n podr√≠a llevar a nuevos tratamientos que usen estas c√©lulas para reparar el cuerpo o comprender mejor problemas inmunol√≥gicos.

**Resumen en una frase** ‚Äì Peque√±as c√©lulas compartidas entre madres y beb√©s viven dentro de nosotros y podr√≠an cambiar c√≥mo entendemos la salud, la curaci√≥n y el sistema inmunol√≥gico.
articles.image_prompt: A warm, detailed painting of two intertwined, translucent cellular structures glowing softly, one containing a subtle pattern of a Y chromosome symbol made of delicate light strands, set against a gentle, abstract background of flowing organic shapes that represent shared life and cellular exchange within the human body.
